YANKEE:
DALLAS:
suppose, that it's as hard for a foreigner to make an impression in
Russia as anywhere on earth.
Most assuredly.
Well, I turned up when I was nineteen at St. Petersburg, which is their
capital. Isn't that right, Mr. Dallas?
Perfectly correct. I was stationed at the Embassy at that time, when
this gentleman appeared with his bony arms sticking out of his coat
sleeves, his trousers half-way up to his knees, and his pockets full of.,
what were they full of in those days?
Coppers and ten-penny nails, I reckon, mostly. Anyway, I just walked
in just as I was, as proud as could be:
-SNEAK UNDER PRECEDING SPEECH: BRING HP AND TAKE OUT.
Morning. I've just coma out here to trade, with a few Yankee notions,
and I want to get a sight of the Emperor; what do they him, the
Tsar?
Well, sir, why do you wish to see him?
Cause I've brought him a present, all the way from America. I respect
him considerable, and I want to get at him to give it to him with ay
own hands.
I ought to warn you it's such a common thing, my lad. Id waVa crowned
heads a present, expecting something handsome in return that I'm afraid
the Emperor will only consider this a trick. A Yankee trick. What
have you brought him?
A acorn.
An acorn! What under the sun possessed you to bring the Emperor of
